awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: Strategic Plan for the Integration of Nanotechnology in Undergraduate Programs (SPIN-UP)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project at J F Drake State Technical College builds on a very successful previous implementation project and has the goals to expand the number and diversity of STEM educational opportunities for students, to expand the number of minority, female, and first-generation students entering and completing postsecondary STEM education opportunities at Drake State, and to increase the percentage of students retained in and completing postsecondary STEM education programs at Drake State.

The project includes twelve elements to further improve the college's STEM programs and to prepare students for study at 4-year institutions and high-demand, high-wage careers in STEM. They are: nanotechnology integrated across the curriculum, development of a chemistry program, faculty professional development in nanotechnology and chemistry, interactive, 3-D visualization learning objects and a 3-D classroom for STEM courses, Summer Bridge activities emphasizing nanotechnology, summer technology camps for middle school students, a Summer Technology Institute to introduce nanotechnology to secondary school educators, a first-year student coaching program shown to be effective in raising second-year and long-term retention rates, supplemental instruction that places peer mentors and tutors in classrooms to assist faculty and students, faculty and student research projects that can be presented at conferences, virtual learning communities utilizing interconnection between the College's Blackboard Learning Management System and various social network systems, and research on the effectiveness of student coaching, supplemental instruction, and interactive, 3-D learning objects on the retention and learning outcomes of minority, female, first-generation, and economically under-resourced students. This project will prepare veterans, minorities, women, first-generation students, and economically under-resourced students for a broad range of new and exciting, high-wage, high-demand STEM careers.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: J F Drake State Technical College

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: J F Drake State Technical College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Drake State Community and Technical College (Drake State) Strategic Plan for Integrating Nanotechnology in Undergraduate Programs (SPIN-UP) project were a five-year HBCU-UP Implementation Project that builds on the successes and lessons learned in a previous Implementation Project to further address institutional challenges in improving undergraduate STEM education and student outcomes. The SPINUP project continued successful efforts in professional development, curriculum development, student research, pipeline development/outreach, and student support while establishing an integrated education and research program in nanotechnology that addresses the new needs of students and employers in the region. These activities addressed three primary goals: 1) expand the number and diversity of STEM educational opportunities for students in the region; 2) expand the number of minority, female, and first-generation students entering completing postsecondary STEM education opportunities, and 3) increase the percentage of students retained in and completing postsecondary STEM education programs.

Drake State is a two-year, HBCU community and technical college located in Huntsville, Alabama. Since 1961, Drake State has prepared technicians for the local health, hospitality, personal care, construction, manufacturing, and engineering industries as well as offered transferable programs. Drake State offers degrees and certificates in 19 programs organized in five areas of study, including four areas of study that prepare students for careers in STEM-related fields. Specifically, students pursue STEM training in Applied Services, Business & Information Technologies, Engineering Technologies, Health Sciences, and Manufacturing & Applied Technologies. Students completing STEM-related degrees and certificates in these fields are prepared to enter STEM-related jobs and may be eligible for transfer to four-year colleges, including two universities that have articulation agreements with Drake State (i.e., Alabama Agricultural & Mechanical University, Oakwood University, and Athens State University).  Throughout the grant implementation, the STEM-related programs expanded to include Google IT, and Cybersecurity.  The articulation agreements with Jacksonville State University, Alabama State University, and the University of North Alabama have been established as well as the expansion of Dual Enrollment agreements with the local school systems.  

The college classifies seven programs as STEM programs (not including health sciences): Computer Information Systems, Engineering Graphics, Electrical Technology, Heating & Air Conditioning, Industrial Electronics, Industrial Systems, and Machine Tool Technology. Approximately 502 students majored in one of these programs in the 2010-2011 academic year, and 76% of students are retained semester to semester. As reported in the College’s annual report to its accrediting agency, the Council on Occupational Education, 65.1% of its students completed certificate/degree programs in 2010-11 and 82.5% of those students found jobs in their field or transferred to a four-year school. 

Over the subsequent five years, we accomplished many of the original goals of the project, exceeded expectations for student and institutional outcomes in several areas, and gained insight into new challenges. Our annual reports described project activities and outcomes related to our original goals and additional findings.  However, there have been many challenges and changes that occurred including administrative changes, fluctuation in enrollment, and pandemic.  The college has and will continue to focus on filling any gaps in instruction, curriculum development, and professional development to address those needs.  For the last several years, the diversity in high demand occupations and addressing the workforce needs. 

The results from the project highlighted the importance of building foundational goals and objectives in areas of high demand and high wages jobs and more technical education and training which is currently overlapping into STEM-related discipline.  Community colleges have proved and played a significant role in addressing these gaps.  The results from this implementation project at Drake State Community and Technical College have shown the importance of collaboration and professional development. 

Finally, the impact of the summer projects has contributed to the three-percent (3%) increase in the retention rate for the college.  As well as impacting the over ninety percent (90%) increase in the student’s awards in certificates, certification and degrees for the college in the last 5 years.  The project has been a success. 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2022
Modified by: Carolyn Henderson
